jump.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to push yourself up into the air, or over or away from something etc, using your legs
jump.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Fans were jumping up and down (=jumping repeatedly) and cheering.
We managed to jump clear of the car before it hit the wall.
He jumped over the wall and ran off.
jump.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to go over or across something by jumping
jump.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He jumped the gate, landing on the concrete.
jump.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to let yourself drop from a place that is above the ground
jump.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The cats jumped down and came to meet us.
Three people saved themselves by jumping from the window.
jump.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to move quickly or suddenly in a particular direction
jump.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Matt jumped up to answer the phone.
We all jumped in a taxi.
She jumped to her feet and left.
jump.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to make a quick sudden movement because you are surprised or frightened
jump.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Sorry, I didn’t mean to make you jump (=surprise or frighten you).
Don’t shout. I nearly jumped out of my skin (=was very shocked or frightened)!
jump.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to increase or improve suddenly and by a large amount
jump.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Profits jumped to £2.6 million last year.
Norway jumped from ninth to third place.
jump.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to change quickly and often from one idea, place, position etc to another – used to show disapproval
jump.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Cathy kept jumping from one topic to another.
I’ve been jumping about the file instead of working straight through it.
jump.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to move suddenly to a further part of a book, discussion etc leaving out the part in between
jump.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: I’m afraid I jumped a couple of chapters.
The movie suddenly jumped ahead to the future.
jump.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if a machine or piece of equipment jumps, it moves suddenly because something is wrong with it
jump.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Why does the video keep jumping like this?
jump.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Somebody jumped him in the park last night.
jump.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: jump
to push yourself up into the air, over something etc, using your legs
The cat jumped up onto the table.
He jumped over the stream.
His horse jumped the fence successfully.
skip
to move forwards with little jumps between your steps, especially because you are feeling happy
The little girl was skipping down the street.
hop
to jump or move around on one leg
He was hopping around because he’d injured his foot.
leap
to suddenly jump up high or a long way
The deer leapt over the fence.
Tina leapt onto the boat as it was moving away.
Fish were leaping out of the water.
bounce
to jump up and down several times, especially on something that has springs in it
Children love bouncing on beds.
dive
to jump into water with your head and arms first
Zoë dived into the swimming pool.
vault
to jump over something in one movement, using your hands or a pole to help you
He vaulted the ticket barrier and ran for the exit.
Ben tried to vault over the bar.
jump.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an act of pushing yourself suddenly up into the air using your legs
jump.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: the best jump of the competition
a dancer famous for his impressive jumps
jump.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: an act of letting yourself drop from a place that is above the ground
jump.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Douglas made his first 10,000-foot parachute jump yesterday.
jump.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a sudden large increase in an amount or value
jump.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a large or sudden change, especially one that improves things
jump.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: The new law is a great jump forward for human rights.
jump.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a fence, gate, or wall that a person or horse has to jump over in a race or competition
jump.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Her horse cleared all the jumps in the first round.
jump.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to increase suddenly by a large amount
jump.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Share prices jumped by almost 8% yesterday.
jump.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to leave a company or organization, especially because it is not very good or very successful
jump.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Their chairman jumped ship for a similar position with a German electronics firm.
jump.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The company reported an 11% jump in sales last year.
another big jump in crude oil prices
jump.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to have or get an advantage over another person or company
jump.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: AT&T is trying to get a jump on its rivals in the videophone market.
